column1: In the early 1960s a young developer named Ken Behring came from the Midwest and bought land where he could
column2: creating an active adult community of two-bedroom maintenance-free homes.  He called his new city Tamarac
column3: named after the nearby Tamarac Country Club in Oakland Park.In 1963
column4: Behring built and Jesse Pilch sold the city's first development east of State Road 7
column5: Tamarac Lakes Section One and Section Two. Next came two neighborhoods of homes built on a former orange grove called Tamarac Lakes North and The Boulevards. Four of Behring's last developments were Tamarac Lakes South
column6: then the Mainlands of Tamarac Lakes just west of State Road 7
column7: and finally the Woodlands community.The city's early leaders
column8: hoping to preserve Tamarac as a bedroom community
column9: allowed Fort Lauderdale to annex commercial pockets
column10: forever losing land that might have bolstered the city's coffers. In the late 1970s
column11: the city de-annexed a long line of commercial buildings from State Road 7 all the way to Northwest 31 Avenue
column12: but it went along with Behring's vision of Tamarac as a bedroom community. The boundaries were wherever Behring decided to build homes. The city's current eastern boundaries narrow to a sliver from Northwest 31 to 37 Avenues
column13: then widen to the south. The city's easternmost boundary extends below Commercial Boulevard to Northwest 16 Avenue.Behring also named a subdivision he founded in the Pinellas Park area

column1: Broward County Public Schools operates public schools.Elementary schools in the Tamarac city limits include:
Tamarac Elementary SchoolOther elementary schools serving sections of Tamarac include Discovery (Sunrise)
column5: and Lloyd Estates (Oakland Park).Millennium 6-12 Collegiate Academy is the sole public secondary school in Tamarac; it was previously only a middle school
column6: but its high school began operations in 2017. Tamarac has a middle school attendance zone serving the majority of the city (sections of the city limits west of NW 81 Avenue). High school students are not zoned to Tamarac; preference is given to those who attended Millennium middle
column7: and those wishing to attend the high school must be eligible for dual-enrollment with Broward College. Other sections are served by Silver Lakes Middle in North Lauderdale
column8: Lauderdale Lakes Middle in Lauderdale Lakes. and Rickards Middle in Oakland Park.Much of Tamarac is zoned to J.P. Taravella High School in Coral Springs
column9: and Piper High School in Sunrise
column10: with Taravella serving northern areas and Piper serving southern areas. Other sections are assigned to Boyd H. Anderson High School in Lauderdale Lakes and Northeast High School in Oakland Park.The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Miami previously operated the Saint Malachy School in Tamarac.
